questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of his right elbow. He does not recall any trauma to the area. The patient plays tennis recreationally and has recently gone from playing weekly to playing daily in preparation for a local tournament. He has had some pain relief with ibuprofen. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the lateral surface of the right distal humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compression neuropathies that can occur at the elbow are cubital tunnel syndrome, pronator teres syndrome, and posterior interosseus nerve syndrome. Although individuals who practice racket sports are at increased risk of developing these conditions, a compression neuropathy typically results in distal weakness in the affected arm. Cubital tunnel syndrome and pronator teres syndrome usually result in sensory loss and/or paresthesias. This patient has lateral epicondylitis, which is not due to nerve compression.

B) INCORRECT:

Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, which occurs while playing tennis, can cause olecranon bursitis and elbow pain. Affected patients typically present with pain that is localized to the posterior surface of the elbow as well as swelling at the tip of the elbow. The more likely cause of this patient's symptoms is lateral epicondylitis, which is not the result of bursitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive repetitive wrist flexion can cause medial epicondylitis, which manifests with elbow pain. However, the pain is typically located on the medial rather than the lateral surface of the elbow and is exacerbated by forearm pronation and/or wrist flexion. Moreover, repetitive wrist flexion is required in sports such as golf rather than in tennis; medial epicondylitis is also known as “golfer's elbow.”

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive bone stress from submaximal loading is responsible for stress fractures. The most common site for stress fractures near the elbow is the olecranon process, and individuals involved in racket sports are at increased risk of developing this overuse injury. However, olecranon stress fractures typically manifest with pain over the posterior rather than lateral surface of the elbow, and the pain is exacerbated by extension of the forearm against resistance. This patient has lateral epicondylitis, which is not due to excessive stress on the bone.

E) CORRECT:

Lateral epicondylitis is caused by activities that involve repetitive wrist extension and forearm pronation/supination, such as backhand shots in racket sports. The pain can typically be exacerbated by resisted supination, resisted wrist extension, and tight grasping of objects. Lateral epicondylitis is a clinical diagnosis, and imaging is usually not necessary. If performed, musculoskeletal ultrasound typically shows thickening and edema of the tendinous origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis. Initial management consists of conservative treatment including rest, cooling, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and modification of activity (e.g., training proper technique). In patients with severe pain, a local corticosteroid injection may be indicated; note that corticosteroids can cause tendon rupture in insertional tendinopathy. If symptoms do not subside after 6 months of conservative therapy, surgical release of the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon can be considered.
questions.hint: Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a tennis player suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of her left elbow. She does not recall any trauma to the area. The patient plays badminton recreationally. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive bone stress from submaximal loading is responsible for stress fractures. The most common site for stress fractures near the elbow is the olecranon process, and individuals involved in racket sports are at increased risk of developing this overuse injury. However, patients with olecranon stress fractures typically present with pain over the posterior surface of the elbow and exacerbation of pain with extension of the forearm against resistance. Given the pain on the lateral surface of the forearm and exacerbation of pain with wrist extension against resistance seen here, a different diagnosis is likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression neuropathies that can occur at the elbow include cubital tunnel syndrome, pronator teres syndrome, and posterior interosseous nerve syndrome. Although individuals who practice racket sports are at increased risk of developing these conditions, a compression neuropathy would typically result in distal weakness in the affected arm. Cubital tunnel syndrome and pronator teres syndrome would also result in sensory loss and/or paresthesias.

Compression of the posterior interosseous nerve within the radial tunnel occasionally results in pain on the lateral surface of the elbow without motor weakness, sensory deficits, or paresthesias (radial tunnel syndrome). In approximately 5% of patients, radial tunnel syndrome occurs in conjunction with lateral epicondylitis. However, in radial tunnel syndrome, pain typically affects the dorsal aspect of the proximal forearm rather than the distal humerus.

C) INCORRECT:

Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, which occurs while playing racket sports, can cause elbow pain due to olecranon bursitis. However, the pain associated with olecranon bursitis would be localized to the posterior surface of the elbow, and swelling would usually occur at the tip of the elbow. The more likely cause of this patient's symptoms is lateral epicondylitis, which is not the result of bursitis.

D) CORRECT:

The lateral epicondyle is the common origin of the wrist extensors. Lateral epicondylitis is caused by activities, e.g., racket sports such as tennis and badminton, that involve repetitive wrist extension and/or repetitive forearm supination/pronation with the elbow nearly fully extended. In patients with lateral epicondylitis, the pain can be exacerbated by resisted supination, resisted wrist extension, and tight grasping of objects. The most sensitive imaging finding is thickening and edema of the tendinous origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeated wrist flexion can cause medial epicondylitis, which can affect individuals involved in racket sports and manifests with elbow pain. However, the pain would be present on the medial surface of the elbow and it would be exacerbated by forearm pronation and/or wrist flexion. Moreover, medial epicondylitis is 5–10 times less common than lateral epicondylitis.
questions.hint: Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a racket sports enthusiast suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for a 1-month history of right knee pain. The pain is dull, constant, and localized to the lateral aspect of the knee. He denies any trauma to the area. He used to run four miles daily but has stopped due to the pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no erythema or signs of effusion. Pain is elicited when the patient lays on his left side and the examiner passively flexes his right leg while applying pressure over the lateral femoral epicondyle. Knee extension with rotation does not result in pain or an audible snap. After flexing the knee, there is no increased tibial anterior or posterior gliding when the physician pulls the proximal tibia forward or pushes the proximal tibia backward. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury may manifest with knee pain and typically occurs during an athletic activity. However, patients with ACL injuries have a positive anterior draw test, rather than a positive Noble test. Moreover, ACL injuries typically have an acute onset with a popping sensation at the time of injury, followed by knee swelling and instability.

B) INCORRECT:

A lateral meniscus tear can manifest with knee pain that worsens during physical activity. However, meniscus tears are associated with a positive McMurray test, rather than a positive Noble test. Moreover, patients with meniscus tears typically develop joint effusion, restricted knee extension, clicking sounds, inability to squat or kneel, or “locking” of the knee.

C) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) manifests with knee pain that worsens with activities, such as running, and often occurs as an overuse injury in runners. However, patients with PFPS typically present with anterior or peripatellar knee pain and pain after prolonged sitting, with squatting, or climbing stairs. Moreover, a positive Noble test is not expected in patients with PFPS.

D) CORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) manifests with knee pain over the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Noble test. ITBS is an overuse injury that is mainly seen in runners, cyclists, and military personnel. The pain in ITBS is initially sharp or burning, poorly localized, and only present during exercise, but can develop into a deep, dull ache that persists even during rest. ITBS is mainly a clinical diagnosis; treatment includes rest, ice, and NSAIDs during the acute phase, followed by muscle strengthening (e.g., physiotherapy, supervised exercise program) and flexibility exercises (e.g., stretching, use of foam rollers).

E) INCORRECT:

Pes anserine pain syndrome (PAPS) manifests with knee pain and is typically caused by athletic activities, such as running. However, PAPS is not associated with a positive Noble test. Moreover, the knee pain in PAPS manifests along the medial aspect of the knee and proximal tibia, rather than the lateral knee.
questions.hint: Pain upon pressure over the lateral femoral epicondyle while flexing the leg indicates a positive Noble test. Running is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents to the physician with a 3-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of his left elbow. He denies any recent trauma. The pain worsens when he plays badminton, which he practices regularly on the weekends, and is relieved with rest. Osteopathic structural examination reveals:

No bony deformities of the upper extremities
Sensation grossly intact in the upper extremities
Tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus
Tender point along the left extensor carpi radialis
Pain at the lateral elbow when extending the wrist against resistance

The most likely underlying cause of the pain is
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The lateral epicondyle is the common origin of the wrist extensors. Lateral epicondylitis is caused by activities that involve repetitive wrist extension and/or repetitive forearm supination/pronation with the elbow nearly fully extended, e.g., racket sports such as tennis and badminton. Pain in patients with lateral epicondylitis can be exacerbated by resisted supination, resisted wrist extension, and tight grasping of objects. Treatment includes rest, ice, pain management, and physical therapy. Osteopathic techniques should aim to correct any cervical or thoracic spine dysfunctions, relieve myofascial restrictions in the upper extremity, and treat any tender points along the extensor muscles of the forearm (e.g., the extensor carpi radialis muscle).

B) INCORRECT:

Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, which occurs while playing racket sports, can cause elbow pain due to olecranon bursitis. However, the pain associated with olecranon bursitis would be localized to the posterior surface of the elbow, and swelling would usually occur at the tip of the elbow. The more likely cause of this patient's symptoms is lateral epicondylitis, which is not the result of bursitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Compression neuropathies that can occur at the elbow include cubital tunnel syndrome, pronator teres syndrome, and radial tunnel syndrome. Although individuals who regularly play racket sports are at increased risk of developing these conditions, cubital tunnel syndrome and pronator teres syndrome result in sensory loss and/or paresthesias. Additionally, compression neuropathies typically manifest with distal weakness in the affected arm. Radial tunnel syndrome occurs in conjunction with lateral epicondylitis in approximately 5% of patients. In such cases, compression of the posterior interosseous nerve occasionally results in pain on the lateral surface of the elbow without motor weakness, sensory deficits, or paresthesias. However, pain typically affects the dorsal aspect of the proximal forearm rather than the distal humerus.

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive bone stress from submaximal loading is responsible for stress fractures. The most common site for stress fractures near the elbow is the olecranon process, and individuals involved in racket sports are at increased risk of developing this overuse injury. However, patients with olecranon stress fractures typically present with pain over the posterior surface of the elbow and exacerbation of pain with extension of the forearm against resistance. Given the pain on the lateral surface of the forearm and exacerbation of pain with wrist extension against resistance seen here, a different diagnosis is likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeated wrist flexion can cause medial epicondylitis, which can affect individuals involved in racket sports and manifests with elbow pain. However, the pain would be present on the medial surface of the elbow and it would be exacerbated by forearm pronation and/or wrist flexion. Moreover, medial epicondylitis is 5–10 times less common than lateral epicondylitis.
questions.hint: Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a racket sports enthusiast suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman with no significant medical history has pain in her right elbow and forearm that began 2 months ago and has worsened in the past 2 weeks. Initially, she experienced the pain only with movement, especially when she picked up objects, so she tried to rest the affected arm. Now, the pain is more intense and also occurs at rest; she feels it worst on the lateral aspect of the proximal forearm.
She has no other complaints and, although she is an avid weightlifter, has had no trauma. For the past 2 weeks, she has been wearing a forearm counterforce strap and taking ibuprofen 600 mg three times daily, with no relief.
On physical examination, the pain is reproduced on resisted extension of the right wrist. In addition, she has tenderness on palpation of the right lateral epicondyle. She has no pain with active and passive range of motion of the elbow. There is no swelling, rash, or effusion.
Which one of the following initial management approaches is best in this case?

choices.text: Inject platelet-rich plasma at the lateral epicondyle
Inject lidocaine at the lateral epicondyle
Inject a glucocorticoid into the lateral epicondyle
Recommend physical therapy and eccentric exercises to the wrist extensors
Administer a glucocorticoid by iontophoresis to the lateral epicondyle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Platelet-rich plasma injections have little evidence supporting their use; they should be reserved for refractory cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Lidocaine injections have little evidence supporting their use; they should be reserved for refractory cases.

C) INCORRECT:

A large randomized controlled trial showed worsened long-term outcomes in patients with lateral epicondylitis who received glucocorticoid injections than in those who received placebo injections. Glucocorticoid injections should, therefore, be avoided in treating chronic lateral epicondylitis.

D) CORRECT:

Lateral epicondylitis (known as tennis elbow) is a frequent cause of isolated pain in the elbow and forearm. The pain is exacerbated by repetitive sports or occupational activities such as tennis, golf, weightlifting, or construction. On physical examination, individuals have tenderness to palpation at the origin of the common extensor tendons at the lateral epicondyle. Resisted extension of the wrist will reproduce the pain.

Initial treatment of lateral epicondylitis is conservative and includes rest, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, application of ice, physical therapy, and cessation or modification of the activities that exacerbate the symptoms. A splint is also sometimes used, specifically a wrist splint, because the overuse activity usually involves the wrist and not the elbow itself, although neither splints nor forearm counterforce straps have a lot of evidence for effectiveness.

If initial conservative measures fail, then referral to physical therapy is indicated, with initiation of eccentric exercises to the wrist extensors.

Key learning point: Lateral epicondylitis that persists despite conservative measures such as antiinflammatory medicines, rest, splinting, and application of ice is best treated with referral to physical therapy and initiation of eccentric exercises to the wrist extensors.

E) INCORRECT:

Iontophoresis has little evidence supporting its use; it should be reserved for refractory cases.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents with worsening pain in her left elbow. She first noticed the pain 3 weeks ago after playing bass guitar, which she does routinely. The pain worsened dramatically 3 days ago after playing at an all-day music festival. She is now unable to hold a plate or use utensils because of the pain. She denies fevers, chills, fatigue, or other painful joints.
On examination, she has marked tenderness over the lateral proximal forearm and lateral epicondyle, raising suspicion for lateral epicondylitis.
Which one of the following maneuvers is most likely to elicit pain related to this patient’s suspected lateral epicondylitis?

choices.text: Resisted wrist extension with the elbow fully extended
Passive full wrist extension with the elbow fully extended
Resisted wrist flexion with the elbow fully extended
Forced wrist adduction with the thumb flexed under the fingers
Resisted elbow flexion with the wrist pronated

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lateral epicondylitis is a tendon-related pain at the myotendinous junction, where the wrist extensors insert into the lateral epicondyle. The pain, which often occurs after overuse or repetitive motions, is evoked by having a patient extend the wrist against resistance while the elbow is fully extended, which forces use of the muscle and tendon. Pain may also be elicited by maximal passive wrist flexion with the elbow extended, which stretches the tendon.

Key learning point: The maneuver used to confirm lateral epicondylitis involves having the patient extend the wrist against resistance while the elbow is extended.

B) INCORRECT:

In lateral epicondylitis, pain may be elicited by maximal passive wrist flexion with the elbow extended, which stretches the tendon related to lateral epicondylitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Medial epicondylitis results from tendon pain at the insertion of the wrist flexors into the medial epicondyle. Resisted wrist flexion or passive full wrist extension evokes pain that is related to medial epicondylitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Forced wrist adduction with the thumb flexed under the fingers (Eichhoff test) is a nonspecific trigger for pain related to the radial wrist. The Finkelstein test is a more specific maneuver for the diagnosis of de Quervain tenosynovitis. It involves asking the patient to open his or her hand loosely and then grasping the thumb and using it to sharply deviate the hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger.

E) INCORRECT:

Resisted elbow flexion with the wrist pronated tests the biceps muscle and tendons.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man reports a 6-week history of lateral knee pain. He frequently runs long-distance races on uneven terrain. He has no history of injury to the area and has not recently changed his footwear. The pain is localized to the lateral aspect of his right knee, although at times the pain radiates up his thigh. He mainly notices the pain while running, though occasionally when descending a stairway. He has no feeling of instability or episodes of locking in the knee.
On examination, his right knee has full range of motion with no evidence of effusion or warmth. There is tenderness to palpation at the lateral femoral condyle, 2 to 3 cm proximal to the lateral aspect of the right knee. When the patient is supine and the right knee is flexed to 90 degrees, extension of the knee while putting pressure on the lateral femoral condyle causes reproducible pain at 30 degrees flexion. A McMurray test is negative. The patient has full range of motion in his right hip.
A radiograph of the right knee is unremarkable.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s lateral knee pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS), a common cause of lateral knee pain, often radiates to the thigh or even the hip. ITBS classically occurs in avid runners who run on uneven terrain. Point tenderness at the lateral femoral condyle, as well as reproducible pain with the Noble test (flexing the knee from 0 to 60 degrees while keeping pressure on the lateral femoral condyle), are typical findings in patients with ITBS.

Key learning point: A common knee syndrome in athletes complaining of lateral knee pain radiating to the thigh is iliotibial band syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral syndrome and infrapatellar bursitis are less likely than iliotibial band syndrome in this patient, considering the location of the patient’s pain. Patellofemoral syndrome is classically described as anterior peripatellar knee pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral syndrome and infrapatellar bursitis are less likely than iliotibial band syndrome in this patient, considering the location of the patient’s pain. Infrapatellar bursitis is associated with pain and swelling immediately distal and superficial to the patella.

D) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament tear is unlikely, as this generally occurs after an acute event and is associated with significant instability of the knee.

E) INCORRECT:

A meniscal tear is less likely than iliotibial band syndrome in this patient, given the negative McMurray test, the lack of instability symptoms, and the fact that pain from meniscal tears generally does not radiate to the thigh.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents with pain along the lateral aspect of his right knee and along the lateral aspect of his thigh. He is a recreational runner and recently increased his training intensity in preparation for a marathon. The pain occurs after several minutes of running and subsides with rest. It is worse when he runs down a hill or increases his stride length.
On examination, he has normal range of motion in the right knee with no crepitus and no ligamentous instabilities. Extension of the right knee from a flexed position while applying pressure to the lateral femoral epicondyle reproduces the pain at about 30 degrees flexion.
Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the knee are unremarkable.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Osteoarthritis of the lateral compartment of the knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome causes anterior knee pain, worse with ascending or descending stairs. Examination may be normal or may show pain with various maneuvers of the patella.

B) CORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome is a common overuse injury, primarily in runners and cyclists, that is associated with repetitive flexion and extension exercises of the knee. Patients usually have pain in the lateral aspect of the knee where the iliotibial band courses over the lateral femoral epicondyle. Physical examination usually demonstrates reproducible pain with extension of the flexed knee to about 30 degrees flexion while direct pressure is applied over the lateral femoral epicondyle. Treatment typically consists of activity modification and physical therapy.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a recreational runner who has pain along the lateral aspect of the knee and thigh that occurs with repetitive knee flexion and extension is iliotibial band syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral meniscal tears in this age group usually result from a traumatic twisting or pivoting injury. Symptoms include clicking, joint-line tenderness, limited range of motion, locking, and a sensation of the knee giving way.

D) INCORRECT:

Epicondylar stress fractures in runners most frequently occur in the tibia. Pain often occurs at the end of or after a run. Point tenderness and local swelling are typically present.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis of the knee is less common in the lateral than the medial compartment and would be rare in a young person in the absence of severe past trauma. Typical symptoms include pain with activity, swelling, stiffness, and limited range of motion.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old male marathon runner reports a one-month history of right lateral knee pain. He reports no antecedent trauma. He also notes that the pain was initially present only while running but now occurs while walking and that it occasionally radiates to his right thigh and hip.
The patient has tried applying ice and taking acetaminophen to ease his symptoms, without benefit. He has not stopped running.
Which one of the following findings would confirm the diagnosis of iliotibial band syndrome in this patient?

choices.text: Tenderness on palpation at the lateral femoral epicondyle
Positive Lachman or anterior drawer test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Soft-tissue swelling next to the patella is nonspecific but can be present in patients with the plica syndrome. Plicae are embryonic remnants of synovial septations and may become painful after repetitive trauma from running.

B) CORRECT:

The iliotibial band consists of connective tissue on the lateral thigh and leg that runs from the ilium to the proximal tibia. The iliotibial band syndrome, most common in long-distance runners, manifests with pain over the lateral femoral epicondyle. The diagnosis is usually made in a patient with a supporting medical history and tenderness on palpation at the lateral femoral epicondyle, particularly when pressure is applied while the knee is passively extended from 90 degrees with the patient supine (Noble test).

The treatment of iliotibial band syndrome comprises activity modification, massage, and stretching and strengthening of the affected limb, often under the guidance of a physical therapist. Competitive or high-mileage runners may need a comprehensive treatment program, including use of glucocorticoid injection into the site.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a runner who has lateral knee pain with tenderness at the lateral femoral epicondyle is iliotibial band syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Varus and valgus stress tests evaluate for integrity of the lateral and medial collateral ligaments, respectively.

D) INCORRECT:

Varus and valgus stress tests evaluate for integrity of the lateral and medial collateral ligaments, respectively.

E) INCORRECT:

Lachman test evaluates for anterior cruciate ligament injury.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old female marathon runner presents with pain that she initially described as aching in the right groin after activity. Now she reports pain in the groin, the pubic area, anterior hip, and lower abdomen. The pain is exacerbated by running and with pushing off to change direction.
There is tenderness to the pubic bone over the pubic symphysis, and symptoms are reproduced when applying pressure to the pubic ramus on the right side. In addition, the patient experiences pain when she is lying on her side with the right side down and she actively adducts the right leg while downward resistance is applied to the distal medial femur.
There is no pain with hip flexion-adduction-internal rotation (FADIR) testing, nor with rolling of the extended leg into internal rotation when the patient is lying supine. Resisted sit-up and leg elevation do not reproduce symptoms.
Which is the most likely cause of this patient’s pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Athletic pubalgia is a soft-tissue injury in the groin area. Although it is sometimes referred to as a sports hernia, a true hernia is not present. Athletic pubalgia is a clinical diagnosis characterized by unilateral pain in the groin and pain with resisted sit-up and leg elevation.

B) INCORRECT:

Femoral acetabular impingement (FAI) is caused by a cam- or pincer-bone spur that leads to joint damage and pain. Pain in the groin with a hip flexion-adduction-internal rotation (FADIR) test suggests FAI.

C) INCORRECT:

Painful osteoarthritis of the hip is unlikely to have developed in a patient before her 30s.

D) CORRECT:

Osteitis pubis is most common in athletes who participate in sports with running, kicking, and rapid lateral movements. It is generally classified as an overuse injury that causes inflammation of the pubic symphysis from repetitive microtrauma, shearing forces, or both. The adductor and abdominal muscles attach near the pubic symphysis, exerting a pulling force on the symphysis when contracting (e.g., during running, kicking, or sit-ups). When the pain is chronic, a radiograph may show changes in the pubis symphysis, with combinations of sclerosis and lucency.

The most specific physical examination test for osteitis pubis is the direct-pressure spring test, in which the pubic bone is palpated over the pubic symphysis, which generally elicits tenderness. The fingers are then slid a few centimeters laterally to each side, applying pressure on the pubic rami. The test is positive when pain over the pubic symphysis is reproduced with ipsilateral pressure to the pubic rami. A thigh adduction test may be helpful; a positive test elicits exacerbation of pain because the adductor muscles are attached near the pubic symphysis.

Key learning point: The most specific test for osteitis pubis is a direct-pressure spring test.

E) INCORRECT:

Snapping hip syndrome is a benign condition that results from movement, or “snapping,” of the iliopsoas or rectus femoris tendon over a bony protrusion.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman reports 3 months of worsening pain in the lateral right knee that initially developed while she was training for a marathon. There was no precipitating injury. The pain is exacerbated by running, particularly downhill, and appears to be getting worse despite regular icing. It subsides with rest and is not felt during walking or other daily activities. The patient experiences no popping, clicking, locking, or instability. She has never had such symptoms in the past.
No swelling or skin changes are evident. She has tenderness of the lateral femoral condyle a few centimeters above the joint line. The tenderness is worse with 30 degrees of knee flexion. She has full range of motion of her right knee and has 5/5 strength with knee flexion and extension. The rest of her knee examination is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Injection of a glucocorticoid at the point of maximal tenderness
Trial of an oral glucocorticoid with a rapid taper over the course of one week
Rest from running, with stretching, followed by strengthening activities when the pain resolves
Referral to an orthopedic surgeon for evaluation of a possible meniscus tear

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid injection can provide short-term pain relief but is unlikely to have any long-term benefit. It would not be the first-line treatment for IT band syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids are of unclear benefit and have multiple adverse effects. They would not be first-line treatment in a patient like this.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is not the best first step for a patient whose history is most consistent with IT band syndrome. The best strategy is to start with IT band stretching and hip abduction exercises. If the pain and symptoms persist despite an adequate course of physical therapy, MRI can be helpful in showing a bursal pocket over the lateral knee.

D) CORRECT:

Iliotibial (IT) band syndrome is a common overuse condition that results in generalized pain and tenderness of the lateral knee proximal to the joint line. The pain is thought to be caused by friction of the distal IT band at the lateral femoral condyle, but the precise biomechanical cause is unclear. This syndrome frequently occurs in the context of cycling and endurance running.

Initial treatment of IT band syndrome consists of rest from running, activity modification, IT band stretching, and hip abductor strengthening. Cross-training is recommended to maintain physical fitness during rest from running. IT band stretching should be initiated early in the treatment plan, followed by hip abductor strengthening once stretching can be done without pain. Running can eventually be resumed, initially for shorter distances, with a gradual return to the previous level of activity. The resumption can be calibrated independently or under the guidance of a physical therapist.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for iliotibial band syndrome in a distance runner is rest from running, activity modification, iliotibial band stretching, and hip abductor strengthening.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s history and examination are not consistent with a meniscal tear. Even if they were, with these symptoms (and the absence of anything mechanical such as a locked knee), it would still be appropriate to initially refer to physical therapy prior to a surgical evaluation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college student reports a 6-week history of lateral knee pain. He frequently runs long-distance races on uneven terrain. He has no history of injury to the area and has not recently changed his footwear. The pain is localized to the lateral aspect of his right knee, although at times the pain radiates up his thigh. He mainly notices the pain while running, though occasionally when descending a stairway. He has no feeling of instability or episodes of locking in the knee.
On examination, his right knee has full range of motion with no evidence of effusion or warmth. There is tenderness to palpation at the lateral femoral condyle, 2 to 3 cm proximal to the lateral aspect of the right knee. When the patient is supine and the right knee is flexed to 90 degrees, extension of the knee while putting pressure on the lateral femoral condyle causes reproducible pain at 30 degrees flexion. A McMurray test is negative. The patient has full range of motion in his right hip.
A radiograph of the right knee is unremarkable.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s lateral knee pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament tear is unlikely, as this generally occurs after an acute event and is associated with significant instability of the knee.

B) INCORRECT:

Infrapatellar bursitis is less likely than iliotibial band syndrome in this patient, considering the location of the patient’s pain. Infrapatellar bursitis is associated with pain and swelling immediately distal and superficial to the patella.

C) CORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS), a common cause of lateral knee pain, often radiates to the thigh or even the hip. ITBS classically occurs in avid runners who run on uneven terrain. Point tenderness at the lateral femoral condyle, as well as reproducible pain with the Noble test (flexing the knee from 0 to 90 degrees, then exerting constant pressure on the lateral femoral condyle while extending the knee), are typical findings in patients with ITBS.

Key learning point: A common knee syndrome in athletes complaining of lateral knee pain radiating to the thigh is iliotibial band syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

A meniscal tear is less likely than iliotibial band syndrome in this patient, given the negative McMurray test, the lack of instability symptoms, and the fact that pain from meniscal tears generally does not radiate to the thigh.

E) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral syndrome is less likely than iliotibial band syndrome in this patient, considering the location of the patient’s pain. Patellofemoral syndrome is classically described as anterior peripatellar knee pain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 1-month history of right knee pain. The pain is dull, constant, and localized to the lateral aspect of the knee. He used to run four miles daily but has stopped due to the pain. Physical examination shows no erythema or signs of effusion. Pain is elicited when the patient lays on his left side and the examiner passively flexes his right leg while applying pressure over the lateral femoral epicondyle. Knee extension with rotation does not result in pain or an audible snap. After flexing the knee, there is no increased tibial anterior or posterior gliding when the physician pulls the proximal tibia forward or pushes the proximal tibia backward. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury may manifest with knee pain and typically occurs during an athletic activity. However, patients with ACL injuries have a positive anterior draw test, rather than a positive Noble test. Moreover, ACL injuries typically have an acute onset with a popping sensation at the time of injury, followed by knee swelling and instability.

B) INCORRECT:

A lateral meniscus tear can manifest with knee pain that worsens during physical activity. However, meniscus tears are associated with a positive McMurray test, rather than a positive Noble test. Moreover, patients with meniscus tears typically develop joint effusion, restricted knee extension, clicking sounds, inability to squat or kneel, or “locking” of the knee.

C) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) manifests with knee pain that worsens with activities, such as running, and often occurs as an overuse injury in runners. However, patients with PFPS typically present with anterior or peripatellar knee pain and pain after prolonged sitting, with squatting, or climbing stairs. Moreover, a positive Noble test is not expected in patients with PFPS.

D) CORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) manifests with knee pain over the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Noble test. ITBS is an overuse injury that is mainly seen in runners, cyclists, and military personnel. The pain in ITBS is initially sharp or burning, poorly localized, and only present during exercise, but can develop into a deep, dull ache that persists even during rest. ITBS is mainly a clinical diagnosis; treatment includes rest, ice, and NSAIDs during the acute phase, followed by muscle strengthening (e.g., physiotherapy, supervised exercise program) and flexibility exercises (e.g., stretching, use of foam rollers).

E) INCORRECT:

Pes anserine pain syndrome (PAPS) manifests with knee pain and is typically caused by athletic activities, such as running. However, PAPS is not associated with a positive Noble test. Moreover, the knee pain in PAPS manifests along the medial aspect of the knee and proximal tibia, rather than the lateral knee.
questions.hint: Pain upon pressure over the lateral femoral epicondyle while flexing the leg indicates a positive Noble test. Running is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of his right elbow. He does not recall any trauma to the area. The patient plays tennis recreationally and has recently gone from playing weekly to playing daily in preparation for a local tournament. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the lateral surface of the right distal humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compression neuropathies that can occur at the elbow are cubital tunnel syndrome, pronator teres syndrome, and posterior interosseus nerve syndrome. Although individuals who practice racket sports are at increased risk of developing these conditions, a compression neuropathy typically results in distal weakness in the affected arm. Cubital tunnel syndrome and pronator teres syndrome usually result in sensory loss and/or paresthesias. This patient has lateral epicondylitis, which is not due to nerve compression.

B) INCORRECT:

Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, which occurs while playing tennis, can cause olecranon bursitis and elbow pain. Affected patients typically present with pain that is localized to the posterior surface of the elbow as well as swelling at the tip of the elbow. The more likely cause of this patient's symptoms is lateral epicondylitis, which is not the result of bursitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive repetitive wrist flexion can cause medial epicondylitis, which manifests with elbow pain. However, the pain is typically located on the medial rather than the lateral surface of the elbow and is exacerbated by forearm pronation and/or wrist flexion. Moreover, repetitive wrist flexion is required in sports such as golf rather than in tennis; medial epicondylitis is also known as “golfer's elbow.”

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive bone stress from submaximal loading is responsible for stress fractures. The most common site for stress fractures near the elbow is the olecranon process, and individuals involved in racket sports are at increased risk of developing this overuse injury. However, olecranon stress fractures typically manifest with pain over the posterior rather than lateral surface of the elbow, and the pain is exacerbated by extension of the forearm against resistance. This patient has lateral epicondylitis, which is not due to excessive stress on the bone.

E) CORRECT:

Lateral epicondylitis is caused by activities that involve repetitive wrist extension and forearm pronation/supination, such as backhand shots in racket sports. The pain can typically be exacerbated by resisted supination, resisted wrist extension, and tight grasping of objects. Lateral epicondylitis is a clinical diagnosis, and imaging is usually not necessary. If performed, musculoskeletal ultrasound typically shows thickening and edema of the tendinous origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis. Initial management consists of conservative treatment including rest, cooling, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and modification of activity (e.g., training proper technique). In patients with severe pain, a local corticosteroid injection may be indicated; note that corticosteroids can cause tendon rupture in insertional tendinopathy. If symptoms do not subside after 6 months of conservative therapy, surgical release of the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon can be considered.
questions.hint: Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a tennis player suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of his right elbow. He does not recall any trauma. He plays tennis recreationally and recently increased his frequency from weekly to daily in preparation for a local tournament. On examination, there is tenderness over the lateral surface of the right distal humerus, and the pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compression neuropathies that can occur at the elbow are cubital tunnel syndrome, pronator teres syndrome, and posterior interosseus nerve syndrome. Although individuals who practice racket sports are at increased risk of developing these conditions, a compression neuropathy typically results in distal weakness in the affected arm. Cubital tunnel syndrome and pronator teres syndrome usually result in sensory loss and/or paresthesias. This patient has lateral epicondylitis, which is not due to nerve compression.

B) INCORRECT:

Excessive repetitive wrist flexion can cause medial epicondylitis, which manifests with elbow pain. However, the pain is typically located on the medial rather than the lateral surface of the elbow and is exacerbated by forearm pronation and/or wrist flexion. Moreover, repetitive wrist flexion is required in sports such as golf rather than in tennis; medial epicondylitis is also known as “golfer's elbow.”

C) INCORRECT:

Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, which occurs while playing tennis, can cause olecranon bursitis and elbow pain. Affected patients typically present with pain that is localized to the posterior surface of the elbow as well as swelling at the tip of the elbow. The more likely cause of this patient's symptoms is lateral epicondylitis, which is not the result of bursitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive bone stress from submaximal loading is responsible for stress fractures. The most common site for stress fractures near the elbow is the olecranon process, and individuals involved in racket sports are at increased risk of developing this overuse injury. However, olecranon stress fractures typically manifest with pain over the posterior rather than lateral surface of the elbow, and the pain is exacerbated by extension of the forearm against resistance. This patient has lateral epicondylitis, which is not due to excessive stress on the bone.

E) CORRECT:

Lateral epicondylitis is caused by activities that involve repetitive wrist extension and forearm pronation/supination, such as backhand shots in racket sports. The pain can typically be exacerbated by resisted supination, resisted wrist extension, and tight grasping of objects. Lateral epicondylitis is a clinical diagnosis, and imaging is usually not necessary. If performed, musculoskeletal ultrasound typically shows thickening and edema of the tendinous origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis. Initial management consists of conservative treatment including rest, cooling, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and modification of activity (e.g., training proper technique). In patients with severe pain, a local corticosteroid injection may be indicated; note that corticosteroids can cause tendon rupture in insertional tendinopathy. If symptoms do not subside after 6 months of conservative therapy, surgical release of the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon can be considered.

Key learning point: Lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) is caused by repetitive wrist extension and forearm movements, leading to pain over the lateral elbow.
questions.hint: Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a tennis player suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of lateral elbow pain that began after extensive gardening while renovating a home. The pain is worse with gripping and lifting. Examination shows tenderness over the lateral epicondyle and pain with resisted wrist extension. The patient reports taking ibuprofen intermittently with minimal relief and asks about returning to work on the renovation project tomorrow. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Counsel on relative rest with work modifications and analgesic use
Order MRI to confirm diagnosis before treatment
Recommend complete work cessation for 6 weeks with arm immobilization
Advise return to full work duties without restriction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conservative management includes relative rest with activity modification, NSAID use for 7–14 days, and counseling that symptoms usually resolve within 6–12 months. Work modifications rather than complete cessation allow healing while maintaining function.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid injections are reserved for refractory symptoms that persist for 3 months or more despite conservative therapy. Initial management should focus on conservative measures.

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnosis of lateral epicondylitis is clinical, based on history and provocation testing. Imaging is only considered for diagnostic uncertainty, but x-ray rather than MRI would be the initial imaging choice to exclude differential diagnoses.

D) INCORRECT:

Complete work cessation and immobilization are not indicated for lateral epicondylitis. Using the affected limb normally will not cause damage, and relative rest is preferred over complete immobilization.

E) INCORRECT:

Return to full work duties without modification would perpetuate the repetitive strain that caused the condition. While normal limb use will not cause damage, relative rest is important in conservative management.
